sen.j: 守貞親王（もりさだしんのう、治承3年2月28日（1179年4月6日）-貞応2年5月14日（1223年6月14日））は高倉天皇の第二皇子で母は坊門信隆の娘・坊門殖子（七条院）。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Morisada (April 6, 1179 - June 14, 1223) was the second Prince of Emperor Takakura, and his mother was Nobutaka BOMON's daughter, Shokushi BOMON. (Shichijoin)
Imperial Prince Morisada (April 6, 1179 - June 14, 1223) was the second Prince of Emperor Takakura, and his mother was Nobutaka BOMON's daughter, Shokushi BOMON. (Shichijoin)
Imperial Prince Morisada (April 6, 1179 - June 14, 1223) was the second Prince of Emperor Takakura, and his mother was Nobutaka BOMON's daughter, Shokushi BOMON. (Shichijoin)

sen.j: 安徳天皇は異母兄、後鳥羽天皇は同母弟にあたる。
sen.e: Emperor Antoku was his half older brother, Emperor Gotoba was his real younger brother.
Emperor Antoku was his half older brother, Emperor Gotoba was his real younger brother.
Emperor Antoku was his half older brother, Emperor Gotoba was his real younger brother.

sen.j: 出家して行助入道親王と名乗ったが、子である後堀河天皇の即位後、異例の太上天皇号を贈られ院政を行うことになった。
sen.e: He entered into priesthood and named Monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo, however after his son, Emperor Gohorikawa succeeded to the throne, he was exceptionally given the title of dajo tenno (a retired emperor) and started the cloister government.
sen.cmt: 太上天皇→dajo tenno[定訳不明]
sen.e: He entered into priesthood and was named Monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo, however after his son, Emperor Gohorikawa succeeded to the throne, he was exceptionally given the title of dajo tenno (a retired emperor) and started the cloistered government.

He entered into priesthood and was named Monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo, however after his son, Emperor Gohorikawa succeeded to the throne, he was exceptionally given the title of dajo tenno (a retired emperor) and started the cloistered government.

sen.j: これを後高倉院という。
sen.e: This is called Gotakakurain.
This is called Gotakakurain.
This is called Gotakakurain.

sen.j: 幼い頃、平知盛に育てられていた関係で、平家が都落ちをした際に皇太子に擬されて、西国に連行される。
sen.e: Since he was brought up by TAIRA no Tomomori when he was small, he was imitated to Crown Prince and was taken to the west part of Japan (Chugoku, Shikoku, Kinki area) after Taira clan escaped from the city.

Since he was brought up by TAIRA no Tomomori when he was small, he was an imitation Crown Prince and was taken to the western part of Japan (Chugoku, Shikoku, Kinki area) after the Taira clan escaped from the city.

Since he was brought up by TAIRA no Tomomori when he was small, he was an imitation Crown Prince and was taken to the western part of Japan (Chugoku, Shikoku, Kinki area) after the Taira clan escaped from the city.

sen.j: 平家滅亡時に救出されて帰京するが、都では既に後鳥羽天皇が即位していた（ちなみに『増鏡』では、守貞親王と尊成親王（後鳥羽天皇）が後白河法皇の前に呼ばれて、すぐに法皇に懐いた尊成が皇位に立てられたとする記述があるが、実際に尊成とともに呼ばれたのは守貞親王の異母弟惟明親王（高倉天皇第三皇子）といわれており、これについては『増鏡』作者による「演出説」と「勘違い説」に分かれている）。
sen.e: He went back to Kyoto when the Taira clan died out, however Emperor Gotoba had already succeeded to the throne in Kyoto. (By the way in "Masukagami (The Clear Mirror) it is said Imperial Prince Morisada and Imperial Prince Takahira (Emperor Gotoba) were called in by the cloister Emperor Goshirakawa, and Takahira, who took to the Emperor before Morisada, was appointed to succeed to the throne, however there was another theory that it was Morisada's half younger brother, Imperial Prince Koreaki (Emperor Takakura's third Prince) who was called with Takahira, but there were two different theories of the author of 'Masukagami', one was 'the direction theory' and another one was 'the misunderstanding theory'.

He went back to Kyoto when the Taira clan died out, however Emperor Gotoba had already succeeded to the throne in Kyoto. (in "Masukagami" (The Clear Mirror) it is said Imperial Prince Morisada and Imperial Prince Takahira (Emperor Gotoba) were called in by the cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, and Takahira, who took to the Emperor before Morisada, was appointed to succeed to the throne, however there was another theory that it was Morisada's half younger brother, Imperial Prince Koreaki (Emperor Takakura's third Prince) who was called with Takahira, but there were two different theories of the author of 'Masukagami,' one was 'the direction theory' and another one was 'the misunderstanding theory.'

He was saved and went back to Kyoto when the Taira clan died out, however Emperor Gotoba had already succeeded to the throne in Kyoto. (in "Masukagami" (The Clear Mirror) it is said Imperial Prince Morisada and Imperial Prince Takahira (Emperor Gotoba) were called in by the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa, and Takahira, who took to the Emperor before Morisada, was appointed to succeed to the throne, however there was another theory that it was Morisada's half younger brother, Imperial Prince Koreaki (Emperor Takakura's third Prince) who was called with Takahira, but there were two different theories of the author of 'Masukagami,' one was 'the direction theory' and another one was 'the misunderstanding theory.'

sen.j: 後に持明院基家の娘持明院陳子（後の北白河院）を妃にして持明院家ゆかりの持明院を御所としていたが、自らの不遇を嘆いて建暦2年（1213年）3月に出家してしまう。
sen.e: Later on the Prince Morisada had Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter, Chinshi/Nobuko JIMYOIN (later called Kitashirakawain) as his Empress and he lived in Jimyoin Imperial Palace which was related to Jimyoin family, however he deplored his misfortune and entered into the priesthood in March 1213.

Later on, Prince Morisada had Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter, Chinshi/Nobuko JIMYOIN (later called Kitashirakawain) as his Empress and he lived in the Jimyoin Imperial Palace which was related to the Jimyoin family, however he deplored his misfortune and entered into the priesthood in March 1213.

Later on, Prince Morisada had Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter, Chinshi (also pronounced Nobuko) JIMYOIN (later called Kitashirakawain) as his Empress and he lived in the Jimyoin Imperial Palace which was related to the Jimyoin family, however he deplored his misfortune and entered into the priesthood in April and May 1213.
sen.cmt: also pronounced補足グレゴリ暦に

sen.j: 以後「行助」と名乗る。
sen.e: After that he nemed '行助'.
After that he was named '行助.'
After that he was named '行助.'

sen.j: ところが、8年後の承久3年（1221年）、承久の乱の敗北による後鳥羽上皇らの流罪によって治天の君が不在となる。
sen.e: However eight years later, in 1221, there was no one to rule the government as Chiten no kimi after the retired Emperor Gotoba lost the battle of the Jokyu Disturbance and he was sentenced to deportation.
However eight years later, in 1221, there was no one to rule the government as Chiten no kimi after the retired Emperor Gotoba lost the battle of the Jokyu Disturbance and he was banished.
However eight years later, in 1221, there was no one to rule the government as Chiten no kimi after the Retired Emperor Gotoba lost the battle of the Jokyu Disturbance and he was banished.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府は仲恭天皇を廃位し、「後鳥羽上皇の子孫の皇位継承は認めない」とする方針を決定、非後鳥羽系皇族の擁立を図った。
sen.e: The Kamakura bakufu let Emperor Chukyo abdicated from the throne and decided the policy 'Not to let the retired Emperor Gotoba's descendants to succeed to the throne', and they tried to set up Imperial family member to succeed to the throne who was not Emperor Gotoba's Imperial family.

The Kamakura bakufu let Emperor Chukyo abdicate the throne and decided to institute a new policy 'Not to allow retired Emperor Gotoba's descendants succeed to the throne,' and they tried to set up an Imperial family member to succeed, who was not a member of Emperor Gotoba's Imperial family.

The Kamakura bakufu let Emperor Chukyo abdicate the throne and decided to institute a new policy 'Not to allow Retired Emperor Gotoba's descendants succeed to the throne,' and they tried to set up an Imperial Family member to succeed, who was not a member of Emperor Gotoba's Imperial Family.

sen.j: このとき、親王の3男・茂仁王以外に出家していない皇族がいないことが判明したため、茂仁王を即位（後堀河天皇）させ、行助入道親王を特別に治天の君として、院政を行わせる事になった。
sen.e: At that time, it was found out that there was only Imperial Prince Morisada's third son, Imperial Prince Yutahito was available who did not enter into the priesthood, so it was decided to let Imperial Prince Yutahito succeed to the throne (Emperor Gohorikawa) and especially appointed monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo as Chiten no kimi to rule the cloister government.

At that time, it was found out that there was only Imperial Prince Morisada's third son, Imperial Prince Yutahito available who did not enter into the priesthood, so, it was decided to let Imperial Prince Yutahito succeed to the throne (Emperor Gohorikawa) and especially appointed monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo as Chiten no kimi to rule the cloistered government.

At that time, it was found out that there was only Imperial Prince Morisada's third son, Imperial Prince Yutahito available who did not enter into the priesthood, so, it was decided to let Imperial Prince Yutahito succeed to the throne (Emperor Gohorikawa) and especially appointed monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo as Chiten no kimi to rule the cloistered government.

sen.j: 治天となった親王は承久の乱直後の朝廷内の混乱を鎮めて幕府との関係を再構築するなどの実績を残したものの、その翌々年には病死し、院号（後高倉院）を贈られた。
sen.e: The Imperial Prince who became Chiten, worked on calming the confusion inside the Imperial Palace after the Jokyu Disturbance, and restore the relationship with the bakufu, but he dies two years after that, and was given the ingo (a posthumous title given to an emperor) (Gotakakurain).

The Imperial Prince who became Chiten, worked on calming the confusion inside the Imperial Palace after the Jokyu Disturbance, and to restore the relationship with the bakufu, but he died two years later, and was given the ingo (a posthumous title given to an emperor) (Gotakakurain).

The Imperial Prince who became Chiten, worked on calming the confusion inside the Imperial Palace after the Jokyu Disturbance, and to restore the relationship with the bakufu, but he died two years later, and was given the ingo (a posthumous title given to an emperor) (Gotakakurain).

sen.j: 治承3年（1179年）2月28日 誕生
sen.e: Born on February 28, 1179
Born on February 28, 1179
Born on April 13, 1179

sen.j: 文治5年（1189年）11月19日 親王宣下、無品
sen.e: He was titled to be Imperial Prince without a court rank on November 19, 1189.
He was titled to be Imperial Prince without a court rank on November 19, 1189.
He was titled to be Imperial Prince without a court rank on January 4, 1190.

sen.j: 建久2年（1191年）12月26日 元服・加冠、三品親王
sen.e: He had a coming-of-age ceremony and a first coronation ceremony, and was given an Imprial Prince with the third court rank on December 26, 1191.
sen.cmt: 加冠→first coronation[定訳不明] 三品親王→an Imperial Prince with the third court rank[定訳不明]
sen.e: He had a coming-of-age ceremony and a first coronation ceremony, and was given the title Imperial Prince with the third court rank on December 26, 1191.
He had a coming-of-age ceremony and a first coronation ceremony, and was given the title Imperial Prince with the third court rank on January 19, 1192.

sen.j: 建暦2年（1212年）3月26日 出家、行助入道親王
sen.e: He entered into priesthood and became monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo March 26, 1212.
He entered into the priesthood and became monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo on March 26, 1212.
He entered into the priesthood and became monk-Imperial Prince Gyojo on May 6, 1212.

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）8月 太上天皇
sen.e: He became retired Emperor in August 1221.
He became a retired Emperor in August 1221.
He became a retired Emperor in August and September 1221.

sen.j: 貞応2年（1223年）5月14日 崩御
sen.e: He died on May 14, 1223.
He died on May 14, 1223.
He died on June 21, 1223.

sen.j: 妃・皇子女
sen.e: Empress, Princes and Princesses
Empress, Princes and Princesses
Empress, Princes and Princesses

sen.j: 持明院（藤原）陳子（北白河院）（1173-1238） - 中納言持明院基家女
sen.e: Jimyoin Imperial line (FUJIWARA no) Chinshi/Nobuko (Kitashirakawain) (1173 - 1238) - Chunagon (equivalent rank to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank)), Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter
Jimyoin Imperial line (FUJIWARA no) Chinshi/Nobuko (Kitashirakawain) (1173 - 1238) - Chunagon (equivalent rank to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank)), Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter
Jimyoin Imperial line (FUJIWARA no) Chinshi, also pronounced Nobuko (Kitashirakawain) (1173 - 1238) - Chunagon (equivalent rank to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank)), Motoie JIMYOIN's daughter

sen.j: 第一皇子：尊性法親王（二品天台座主）（1194-1239）
sen.e: The first Prince : Monk-Imperial Prince Sonsho (the second court rank for Imperial Princes of the head priest of Tendai sect of Buddhism) (1194 - 1239)
sen.cmt: 二品→the second court rank for Imperial Princes[定訳不明]
sen.e: The first Prince: Monk-Imperial Prince Sonsho (the second court rank for Imperial Princes of the head priest of Tendai sect of Buddhism) (1194 - 1239)
The first Prince: Cloistered Imperial Prince Sonsho (the second court rank for Imperial Princes of the head priest of Tendai sect of Buddhism) (1194 - 1239)

sen.j: 第一皇女：利子内親王（式乾門院）（1197-1251） - 斎宮、四条天皇准母
sen.e: The first Princess : Imperial Princess Richi (Shikikenmonin) (1197 - 1251) - Saigu (an unmarried princess who, in former times, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine), Emperor Shijo's Junbo (equivalent rank to Emperor's birth mother)

The first Princess: Imperial Princess Richi (Shikikenmonin) (1197 - 1251) - Saigu (an unmarried princess who, in former times, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine), Emperor Shijo's Junbo (equivalent rank to Emperor's birth mother)

The first Princess: Imperial Princess Rishi (Shikikenmonin) (1197 - 1251) - Saigu (an unmarried princess who, in former times, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine), Emperor Shijo's Junbo (equivalent rank to Emperor's birth mother)

sen.e: The second Princess : Imperial Princess Yoshiko (Oshikojinomiya) (1200 - 1245)
The second Princess: Imperial Princess Yoshiko (Oshikojinomiya) (1200 - 1245)
The second Princess: Imperial Princess Yoshiko (Oshikojinomiya) (1200 - 1245)

The third Princess: Imperial Princess Motoko (? - 1229)

sen.e: The second Prince : Monk-Imperial Prince Doshin (The Second court rank for Imperial Princes of Gon no Daisozu (the highest official rank given to the person in charge of managing monks)) (1206 - 1249)

sen.e: The fourth Princess : Imperial Princess Hoshi/Kuniko (Ankamonin) (1209 - 1283) - Emperor Gohorikawa's Junbo
The fourth Princess: Imperial Princess Hoshi/Kuniko (Ankamonin) (1209 - 1283) - Emperor Gohorikawa's Junbo
